channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bombing Kills More Than 140 in Baghdad
item.media:description: Fires were still burning Sunday morning at the site of a bombing in a busy area of cafes, shops and hotels in Baghdad.
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack in a middle-class neighborhood, the deadliest assault in years in the Iraqi capital.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN, TIM ARANGO and OMAR AL-JAWOSHY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ISIS Bombing Casts Doubt on Iraqi Leader’s Ability to Unite
item.media:description: People gathered on Sunday at the scene of a car bombing that killed more than 150 people in Karrada, a busy shopping district in Baghdad.
item.description: After 150 were killed in a car bombing in Baghdad, Iraq’s leader has tried to assuage the public’s anger and grief by speeding the executions of militants.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: After Attacks, Lebanese Christian Town Casts Wary Eye on Syrian Refugees
item.media:description: A young Christian at the funeral of a relative killed in a suicide attack in Al Qaa, Lebanon, last week. Last Monday, two waves of suicide bombers blew themselves up in the village, leaving five men dead and wounding dozens.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: A wave of deadly suicide bombings in the quiet town of Al Qaa has strained a tenuous coexistence between residents and newcomers fleeing Syria’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Dhaka Victims Were a Diverse Group of Global Citizens
item.media:description: Adele Puglisi
item.description: Among the 20 victims were Italian entrepreneurs, Japanese engineers, students from America and a Bangladeshi activist. Here is what we know about them.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: After Slaughter, Bangladesh Reels at Revelations About Attackers
item.description: The men tied to the bloody restaurant siege in Dhaka, all in their late teens and early 20s, were products of Bangladesh’s elite.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservative Mudslinging, and George Osborne Calls for Tax Cuts
item.media:description: Thousands demonstrated in London on Saturday against a British exit from the European Union.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Michael Gove was criticized as having an “emotional need to gossip,” and Mr. Osborne said that he wanted to reduce Britain’s corporate tax to 15 percent.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Nigel Farage Says He’ll Step Down as Head of U.K. Independence Party
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, the leader of the right-wing U.K. Independence Party, in London on Monday. He said he had achieved his central ambition of getting Britain to leave the European Union, and was leaving his party in a “pretty good place.”
item.description: A leader of the campaign for Britain to leave the European Union, Mr. Farage remains a member of the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Upsets Londoners Who Find Harmony in a Cultural Cacophony
item.media:description: Thousands demonstrated in London on Saturday against the “Brexit” result. Sixty percent of voters in the city wanted Britain to remain in the European Union.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: London, where 100 languages are spoken and three million residents come from other countries, can feel like a world apart. The referendum provided the latest reminder.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: Letter From Europe: Chaotic Building Spree Dismays Some in Seaside Georgian City
item.media:description: The architectural ambitions of former President Mikheil Saakashviliv of Georgia were seemingly unlimited, especially in Batumi, which he hoped to turn into a vacation destination.
item.description: A former president’s determination to give Georgia a more contemporary look has left Batumi’s skyline a bizarre mash-up of architectural styles.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Malaysia Links Nightclub Attack to Islamic State
item.media:description: Forensic specialists investigating the explosion at a nightclub in Puchong, Malaysia, late last month that the authorities now believe was the work of Islamic State.
item.description: The episode, which wounded eight people in Puchong, was thought to have been the first assault in Malaysia tied to the militant group.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Israelis’ Favorite Thing About Donald Trump? His Style (to Put It Bluntly)
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, at a campaign event in Dallas last month.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: While Israelis have mixed views of Mr. Trump’s policy proposals, they admiringly describe him as “dugri,” a slang Hebrew term derived from the Arabic for “straight ahead.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Australian Candidates Woo Allies as Election Deadlock Continues
item.media:description: Voters waited to cast their ballots in Bondi Beach, near Sydney, Australia, over the weekend.
item.description: Neither the governing Liberal National coalition nor the Labor Party won enough seats outright to form a government.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Ling Jihua, Ex-Presidential Aide in China, Gets Life Sentence for Corruption
item.media:description: Ling Jihua, once a top aide to former President Hu Jintao, in 2013. He joins two other notable senior party officials in receiving a lifetime prison sentence for graft.
item.description: Mr. Ling joins two other notable senior party officials in receiving a lifetime prison sentence for graft.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Netanyahu Traces Path to Power Back to Entebbe, and Lost Brother
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his wife, Sara, during a ceremony on Monday to commemorate a hostage rescue in Entebbe, Uganda. Mr. Netanyahu’s brother Yonatan, an Israeli commando, was killed in the raid 40 years ago. Bullet holes still scar the control tower at the old airport.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is going to Uganda 40 years after the daring raid that killed his brother and propelled him into politics.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Suicide Attack in Saudi Arabia and Arrests in Kuwait Add to Terrorism Fears
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard near the United States Consulate in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, after a suicide bomber detonated explosives Monday morning.
item.description: The developments, during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, followed a bloody week of assaults in Turkey, Bangladesh and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Drone Strike Statistics Answer Few Questions, and Raise Many
item.media:description: Monitoring Air Force drone footage from Afghanistan in 2010.
item.description: The Obama administration’s release of the civilian death toll from targeted drone attacks revealed an uncertainty about whom it had killed.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: White House Letter: Obama Will Need His Oratory Powers to Sell Globalization
item.media:description: President Obama’s news conference in Ottawa last week with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico was dominated by questions about Donald J. Trump and Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.description: At a time when Donald J. Trump and the pro-“Brexit” crowd are preaching nativism and nationalism, the president undertakes the delicate task of arguing the opposite.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Poland’s Conservative Government Puts Curbs on State TV News
item.media:description: Piotr Maslak was a journalist at Poland’s state television and the first one to be fired under the new conservative government.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times.
item.description: The right-wing Law and Justice Party’s effort to impose its nationalist message on the state broadcaster has prompted wide concern about press freedom.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Chengdu Journal: In China, the ‘Noisiest Park in the World’ Tries to Tone Down Rowdy Retirees
item.media:description: People’s Park in Chengdu, China, has become famous for its often-raucous spectacle. For years, choirs, bands and dance groups, mostly run by older residents, have jostled for space, audiences and glory.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: It gets raucous in People’s Park, where older performers jostle for space, audiences and exercise, and some city residents have had enough of the din.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: As ISIS Loses Land, It Gains Ground in Overseas Terror
item.media:description: A Bangladeshi police officer overseeing a group of peace activists who sang and lit candles in a park on Sunday after a bloody siege at a restaurant in the capital, Dhaka. The attackers had declared allegiance to the Islamic State.
item.description: The Islamic State, the only terrorist group to actually create a state with borders, is becoming a larger, more sophisticated version of its stateless rival, Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Emirates Warn Against Traditional Clothing Abroad After Man Is Mistaken for Terrorist in Ohio
item.media:description: An image from a YouTube video of an Emirati man’s release after he was mistakenly detained by the police in Avon, Ohio.
item.description: A businessman from Abu Dhabi was confronted by armed officers after a hotel clerk said she had overheard him pledging allegiance to ISIS, but the police later apologized.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Elie Wiesel Is Recalled at Funeral for a Legacy Beyond His Moral Voice
item.media:description: After Elie Wiesel’s funeral at the Orthodox Fifth Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan on Sunday. about About 100 people attended the ceremony.
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.description: A small gathering of relatives and friends attended a funeral in Manhattan for Mr. Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and writer who died on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MASLIN NIR and ANNIE CORREAL

item.title: Patrick Manning, Former Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago, Dies at 69
item.media:description: Patrick Manning in 2009. Mr. Manning worked as a geologist before moving into politics and twice serving as prime minister of Trinidad and Tobago.
item.description: Mr. Manning led the resource-rich Caribbean nation through a boom in its petrochemical sector until his party was defeated amid rising crime.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ISIS Uses Ramadan as Calling for New Terrorist Attacks
item.media:description: Muslim worshipers praying late Saturday outside the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem in observance of Lailat al Qadr, or Night of Destiny, which is a part of Ramadan.
item.description: Muslims widely consider Ramadan to be, in part, a time of extra reward for noble acts, but jihadists have used it to inspire more killing.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sex May Spread Zika Virus More Often Than Researchers Suspected
item.media:description: A couple in Rio de Janeiro last year. Intimate contact may account for more Zika infections than previously suspected, though recent findings have been disputed.
item.description: It’s not just mosquitoes: Two reports suggest that women in South America, especially of childbearing age, are likelier to be infected than men.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: What in the World: Proud to Live in a Town Called Dildo
item.description: Residents of Dildo, Newfoundland, are eager to dispel misguided notions about where their town got its name.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: How Do You Say ‘Welcome to Europe’ in Maltese? Check an Arabic Dictionary
item.description: About a third of the words, not to mention the language’s grammar, are derived from the Arabic that was spoken by Muslim settlers of the Mediterranean islands.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: In China, Cheese Is Strange, but Pizza Is Hot
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin / Love_Life / Boarding1Now / iStock.com
item.description: Dairy is not part of the mainstream Chinese diet, but one cheese seller’s prospects may improve as fast food, especially pizza, catches on.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Near U.S. Consulate in Jidda, Saudi Arabia
item.description: The early-morning blast, near a hospital across from the consulate, injured two people, according to the Saudi state news agency.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Kuwait Says It Thwarted 3 Planned ISIS Attacks
item.description: The Interior Ministry said security agencies had arrested a number of Islamic State militants, foiling plots that included a plan to blow up a Shiite mosque.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Contributing Opinion Writer: After Brexit, Can Germany Lead Europe Alone?
item.description: The British exit from the E.U. has put Angela Merkel and her colleagues in a tough position amid nationalistic shifts on the Continent.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Horror and Sorrow in Dhaka
item.media:description: Policemen outside the Dhaka’s central jail in Bangladesh on June 12. The police arrested more than 11,000 people last month, supposedly in a crackdown on terrorism.
item.description: A terrorist attack on a café has struck a blow against Bangladesh’s very idea of itself.
item.dc:creator: TAHMIMA ANAM

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why Frexit Won’t Happen
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Front, at the Élysée Palace in June.
item.description: The European idea was in large part a French idea — a way to access power again.
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
